A 'Variable' is like a box that a computer uses to store data. Variables allow computers to store a single item of data, and access it later when required.
 
The word 'variable' means 'changeable' - data stored inside variables can be changed. This makes them extremely useful things that make up the building blocks of most computer programs.

Variables are made up of 3 essential parts:
 	 • A Name (In orange)
 	 • A Type (In blue)
 	 • A Value (In green)

It is important to name variables in a meaningful way, so that it is clear what each variable is being used for.

 For example, 'int age = 21' is an integer type variable that contains the age of something.
 This is easy to see thanks to the meaningful name.
 ► 'int' (integer) is the variable's type. 
 ► 'age' is the variable's name. 
 ► '21' is the variable's value.

Variable names should also follow a consistent style throughout your code, this will keep your code easy-to-read and maintain. Variables cannot use spaces in their names! 

Several common variable naming styles:
\n An \'Array\' is a list of variables - these allow programmers to store many variables in a more efficient way than having a large group of variables.\n

Left - week day variables / Right - An array of week days.
 Values stored inside arrays can be accessed anytime, similarly to variables. You should note that when accessing the array value "Thursday" below, array item 3 is accessed despite "Thursday" being the fourth value. 
This is because arrays count by starting at zero.
\n Operators are special symbols that allow programmers to use the values stored inside variables and arrays.

There are many different kinds of operators, we will cover the most commonly used ones: 

 	 ► Arithmetic operators 
 	 ► Conditional operators 
 	 ► Logic operators
Arithmetic operators are used to perform mathematical functions, like adding two values together. These operators will return a numerical value - the answer to the maths question.\n
\nConditional operators are used to compare values. These operators return a boolean value based on the comparison, for example (12 > 5) would return TRUE, since 12 is greater than 5.\n

The 'equals' operator appears in both the arithmetic and conditional operator sets.
 ► A single symbol (=) sets one value to be equal to another.
 ► A double symbol (==) compares one value to another.

Logical operators take boolean values as input, and return another value based on the operator used.
 ► AND - returns true if the values being compared are \*both\* true.
 ► OR - returns true if \*either\* of the values being compared are true.
 ► NOT - inverts the boolean value.

► (TRUE && FALSE) = FALSE
 ► (TRUE && TRUE) = TRUE
 ► (TRUE || FALSE) = TRUE
 ► (FALSE || FALSE) = FALSE
 ► (!FALSE) = TRUE

Certain keywords in programming allow you to control the flow of a program, depending on certain conditions.
 ► IF 
 ► ELSE 
 ► SWITCH
These keywords let the program select which sections of code should be used, and which should be skipped - without having a person intervene.\n

The flowchart here represents a simple case of selection. 
The diamond shape represents the 'if' statement. It checks the value that is passed into it, and chooses which path to go down based on the result.
 ► If the car has fuel, it doesn't need filled.
 ► If the car is empty, it needs filled.

The screenshot below shows the car fuel tank flowchart example as code.
 ► The 'if' section will check the value first.
 ► If the result is true, the code inside here will run.
 ► The 'else' section will run if the result was false.

Here is a slightly more complex version of the car fuel tank example.
 There are two 'if' sections here, these will check their conditions one at a time.
 If neither of them are true, then the 'else' section will be used instead.
 
Once one of the sections has been used, the others will not check their conditions - the program will move on.

► The first 'if' will run if the tank is less than a quarter full.
 ► The second will run instead, if the tank is less than half full, but more than a quarter full.
 ► The final section will run if the tank if more than half full.

The 'switch' statement works similarly to 'if'.
 It receives an integer value and compares it to its 'case' values. If there is a match, the matching section of code will run.
 
These are much faster than using many 'if else' statements together - and far easier to maintain.

Loops are pieces of code that will repeatedly execute until either a condition is met (conditional loops), or until the loop has repeated a certain number of times (fixed loops).

 The keywords for loops are: 
 ► 'FOR' 
 ► 'WHILE'

The flowchart above shows the concept of a 'for' loop.
 This loop will keep executing its code until the counter variable is greater than 10. Each time the code is executed, the counter value is increased by 1.

The screenshot above shows the same for loop as in the flowchart, written in code. 
 Let's break down the stuff inside the brackets:

 ► int counter = 0
 The first section here creates the integer value 'counter' and sets it to 0.

 ► counter < 10
 This is the condition that the loop will check for. The loop will repeat until this condition is false.

 ► counter++ 
 The final section will cause the counter variable to increment each time the loop restarts. 'counter++' is the same as writing 'counter = counter + 1'.

\nThe flowchart above shows the concept of a \'while\' loop. This kind of loop will repeatedly execute until a certain condition is met. \nThe loop will repeat until the boolean variable \'flag\' is false.

The code here is a while loop, which will continue to execute its code until the condition is false.
 
 In this example, number will increase by 1 each time the loop runs. Once number is > 3, the flag value will be set to false - this will end the while loop.

Functions are blocks of code that can be re-used, preventing the need to rewrite the same code multiple times over. 

 Functions can take values as input, and can return a new value as output. However, you can also have functions with no input or output.

Most programming languages come with built in functions, here are a couple of common ones:
 ► length - returns the number of characters in a String value
 ► size - returns the number of values inside an array 
 ► print - sends the value to be displayed on screen for the user

The code above shows a function that receives two integer values as input, then adds them together and returns the result.
 
 A function requires a name and a type - in this example the name is 'addTwoNumbers' and the type is 'int'. 

The data type of the function determines what type of value it can return. For example, an int type function can only return integer values. 

A function that does not return a value should have the type 'void'. The function shown below receives a String value and displays it on screen for the user.

If the function receives input values, the type of each value must be specified so that the function knows what to expect.
 
 Functions can be accessed and used like seen below:
\nThe function receives the numbers \'5\' and \'8\', so the returned value would be \'13\'.\n

Here, the same function is accessed multiple times by a for loop.
 
If the original value of 'total' is 13, then after one cycle through the loop, 'total' would be 16 (then 19, 22 etc).
 
The function will continually add 3 to the value 'total', since we are passing these values to the function as input.

string-array.name: vars_questions
string-array.item: What is a String data type?
What is an Integer data type?
What is a Boolean data type?
What is a Float data type?
What is the data type of the array?
What is the camel case naming convention?
What is the pascal case naming convention?
What is the snake case naming convention?

string-array.name: vars_correct_answers
string-array.item: A named container for storing a value
A whole number, negative or positive
A logical value that can be either True or False
A decimal number, negative or positive
Each word in the variable name is capitalized, except the first word
Every word in the variable name is capitalized
Each word in the variable name is separated by underscores

string-array.name: vars_wrong_answers
string-array.item: A logical value that can be either True or False
A very long piece of string
The number of values in an array
A named container for storing a value
Every word in the variable name is separated by commas
Every word in the variable name is separated by underscores
Every word in the variable name is separated by underscores
Every word in the variable name is separated by hyphens
Every word in the variable name is capitalized, except the first
Every word in the variable name is separated by hyphens

string-array.name: oper_questions
string-array.item: Which of these operators are used to assign a value?
Which of these operators are used to increment a value?
Select the operation that gives the value: FALSE
Which of these operators are used to compare values?
Select the operation that gives the value: TRUE

string-array.name: cond_questions
string-array.item: What number is value after this \'switch\'?
What is the purpose of a conditional statement?
What is a conditional statement within another called?
What number is value after the \'switch\'?
What is output by this code? The \'word\' or \'sentence\'?
What is a nested conditional statement?

string-array.name: cond_correct_answers
string-array.item: A conditional statement that will execute its code based on a boolean condition
A conditional statement that will execute a different branch of code depending on a value
A conditional statement that will check a different condition, if the first was false
To execute code based on a certain type of condition
To execute code when the condition is false
A conditional statement within another conditional statement\'s code

string-array.name: cond_wrong_answers
string-array.item: A conditional statement that will execute code based on an array
A conditional statement that will only execute inside a loop
A container for many boolean values
A container for many arrays of values
A conditional statement that will execute a different branch of code depending on a value
To check a list of conditions
To execute a a branch of code multiple times depending on a value
A conditional statement that will only execute inside a loop
A container for many boolean values

string-array.name: loops_questions
string-array.item: What is a loop in programming?
What is the number stored in variable \'b\' at the end of this loop?
What is the purpose of a loop?
What is the purpose of a \'nested\' loop?
What is the number stored in variable \'b\' at the end of this loop?
What is the value of \'sum\' at the end of this loop?

string-array.name: loops_answers
string-array.item: A structure that allows code to be repeatedly executed
To repeatedly execute code a number of times, or until a condition is met
A conditional loop that executes code based on a boolean value
A fixed loop that executes code a certain number of times
A loop that is inside another loop
A value that tracks the number of times a loop has executed
To iterate over the items in an array multiple times

string-array.name: loops_wrong_answers
string-array.item: A structure that executes different code depending on a condition
A named container for storing a value
To separate integer and string data in an array
To output the value held by a variable
A fixed loop that executes code a certain number of times
A loop that is inside another loop
A loop that is inside another loop
The total number of times the loop has executed
A fixed loop that executes code a certain number of times
A condition that causes the loop to execute when met
A value that counts the number of loops used in a program
To select a section of code to run based on a condition
To rename all of the variables used in a section of code

string-array.name: funcs_questions
string-array.item: What is a function in programming?
What is the name of this function?
What is the purpose of a function\'s return statement?
Which of these function data types return no value?
What data type does this function return?
What are the data types of this function\'s parameters?
What is the purpose of functions?
Which of the following shows a function being accessed?
What is the value of \'sum\' that this function returns?

string-array.name: funcs_answers
string-array.item: A reusable section of code that performs a specific task
A variable that receives data the function needs to perform its task
To pass new data back to the code that executed the function
To split code into smaller, more manageable and reusable chunks

string-array.name: funcs_wrong_answers
string-array.item: A structure that executes different code depending on a condition
A named container for storing a value
A value that passes data back from the function
To repeatedly execute code a certain number of times
To check if a condition has been met
To select a section of code to run based on a condition
To repeatedly execute code a certain number of times
